data.title: Who’s Missing from This Spine-Tingling Twin Peaks Teaser?
data.meta_description: A new clip gives us a look at some beloved old characters, but quite a few familiar faces aren’t here.
data.text:
A dark open road. Glitchy spectral music. One spoken word: “Really?” That’s how the latest teaser for the upcoming revival of Twin Peaks, released Thursday, goes—serving more of an aesthetic vibe than curiosity-quenching plot details. (How very Twin Peaks of it.) However, the clip does offer a new glimpse of some of the show’s most iconic characters—without telling us much of what they’re up to.

F.B.I. Special Agent Dale Cooper (Kyle MacLachlan) is back in action looking afraid, very afraid. We also get glimpses of characters like Big Ed Hurley (Everett McGill), Carl Rodd (Harry Dean Stanton), Deputy Andy Brennan (Harry Goaz), and Deputy Tommy "Hawk" Hill (Michael Horse), as well as Sarah Palmer (Grace Zabriskie), mother of Laura—surreptitiously strolling down the liquor aisle of a grocery store.

However, one character from this particular force is missing. Michael Ontkean, who played the memorably named Sheriff Harry S. Truman on the original Twin Peaks, does not appear in the trailer, as he’s retired and has no plans to return to show business. There were rumblings that Robert Forster would be tapped to replace Ontkean, and the actor was later added to the cast of Showtime’s revival, though his role wasn’t specified. Forster was supposed to appear in the original series as well, but he ended up getting tangled up in a pilot that never went anywhere. The actor did eventually work with David Lynch, appearing in the modern classic Mulholland Drive, so this new series is something of a mini reunion for them.

In addition to Forster, there are plenty of other new stars joining the cast this season that aren’t featured in the new teaser. The expanded Twin Peaks world includes actors like Ashley Judd, Jennifer Jason Leigh, and Michael Cera, as well as frequent Lynchian collaborators Naomi Watts and Laura Dern. Here’s hoping we get a fresh glimpse of ’em soon. The Twin Peaks revival will air on May 21.

The 15 Best New TV Characters of 2016

1 / 15

Damn Good Coffee

Laura Dern Spills Details About Twin Peaks Revival: “It’s Brave and Fiery”

With parts in the David Lynch series and the next Star Wars, 2017 might be Dern’s busiest yet.

MAGA

2017’s Hottest Shows Question Whether America Was Ever Great at All

What Riverdale and Twin Peaks tell us about Trump’s famous campaign slogan.

Television

House of the Dragon’s Ser Simon Strong Is “The Only Gentleman in an Ungentlemanly World”

As violence abounds in Westeros, Rhaenyra arranges a secret meeting with Alicent and tries to broker some kind of peace. Plus, Simon Russell Beale drops by Still Watching to discuss the introduction of his new character, the Lord of Harrenhal.

Business

“I’m Not Naive”: Inside Emma Tucker’s Rocky Wall Street Journal Reboot

The British-born editor has injected America’s business paper of record with ambition and verve, while unnerving the newsroom with unapologetic cuts. The restructuring “may look callous,” she says. “But it’s so that we get it right, so I don’t have to do it over again.”

Style

At Le Sirenuse, Vacationing Is a Work of Art

All great hotels have top-notch service and ritzy clientele. But how many have a Nicolas Party at the bottom of the pool?

Hollywood

The Bear Season 4: Everything We Know

The show’s unprecedented use of “to be continued” begs several questions, one of them being: Are we getting new episodes of The Bear sooner than expected?

Politics

The Biden Campaign Needs to Stop Dismissing Critics as “Bed Wetters”

The president is right that his opponent represents a grave threat to American democracy. So why are his surrogates mocking the people who are taking that danger seriously?

Movies

Wicked and Gladiator II Will Be 2024’s Answer to Barbenheimer

Universal Pictures just moved Wicked to November 22, 2024, meaning that it will open the same day as Ridley Scott’s highly anticipated Gladiator sequel, Gladiator II.

Politics

Bannon Assures Podcast Listeners His Show Will Continue During Prison Stint

He’s also said he’ll use his time on the inside to help get Donald Trump reelected.
